results.title: As Strikes Continue in France, Garbage and Resentment Pile Up
results.abstract: After terrorist attacks, floods and other labor strife, a walkout by trash workers was the latest insult just as the weather warmed and fans arrived for the European Championship soccer tournament.

multimedia.caption: Philippe Martinez, the head of a French worker’s union, spoke in front of a chemical factory in southern France on Saturday.
Philippe Martinez, the head of a French worker’s union, spoke in front of a chemical factory in southern France on Saturday.

results.title: Freed From Prison, Zainab al-Khawaja Flees Bahrain
results.abstract: Zainab al-Khawaja, imprisoned for opposing that country’s ruling monarchy, has left the Persian Gulf state in fear of being rearrested and separated from her son.

multimedia.caption: The human rights activist Zainab al-Khawaja was released from prison in May, but fear of re-arrest has led her to flee Bahrain for Denmark.
The human rights activist Zainab al-Khawaja was released from prison in May, but fear of re-arrest has led her to flee Bahrain for Denmark.

results.title: While Young Britons Favor Staying in E.U., They Aren’t Big on Voting
results.abstract: Holding the attention of young voters — and getting them to turn out on June 23 for a referendum on whether Britain should stay in the European Union — is a challenge.

multimedia.caption: Supporters of the “Vote Remain” campaign in London. Young Britons are generally comfortable with a multicultural society, surveys have found, and they value the opportunity to work and travel in 28 European nations without a visa.

Supporters of the “Vote Remain” campaign in London. Young Britons are generally comfortable with a multicultural society, surveys have found, and they value the opportunity to work and travel in 28 European nations without a visa.

results.title: China Tries to Redistribute Education to the Poor, Igniting Class Conflict
results.abstract: A plan to expand higher education to students from impoverished regions, at the expense of the urban middle class, has set off an intense backlash.

multimedia.caption: Students in Mianyang, China, did review work in May as they prepared for the national college entrance exam, known as the gaokao. The exam gives the admissions system a meritocratic sheen, but critics say it reinforces the divide between urban and rural students.

results.title: Explosion Wounds 4 at Airport in Shanghai
results.abstract: The police said the blast, at a check-in counter in one of China’s busiest airports, was set off by a man carrying a homemade explosive.
results.byline: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY

multimedia.caption: Paramilitary officers standing guard at Pudong International Airport in Shanghai after a blast that officials said was set off by a man carrying a homemade explosive.

results.abstract: A building boom in the city’s sacred center has created a dazzling, high-tech 21st-century pilgrimage.

results.title: Bangladesh Arrests Over 3,000 to Halt Attacks
results.abstract: The arrests were part of a series of raids intended to quell a wave of deadly machete attacks against bloggers, minorities and others, the police said.
results.byline: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and GEETA ANAND
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: A crowd in Dhaka, Bangladesh, watching a police raid in February that was part of an effort to halt a wave of brutal attacks on minorities and activists.
A crowd in Dhaka, Bangladesh, watching a police raid in February that was part of an effort to halt a wave of brutal attacks on minorities and activists.

results.title: South Korean Families Watch Ferry’s Salvaging, Hoping Truth Surfaces
results.abstract: Distrustful of the government’s response to the 2014 Sewol disaster, victims’ families have camped out on a rocky island to monitor the salvage operation.

multimedia.caption: Oh Byung-hwan, left, whose son died in the 2014 Sewol ferry disaster, is among the relatives of victims who have camped out on Donggeochado, South Korea, to monitor the ship’s salvaging operation.
multimedia.copyright: Jean Chung for The New York Times

results.title: Doctor’s Plan for Full-Body Transplants Raises Doubts Even in Daring China
results.abstract: Patients suffering from paralysis and muscular wasting diseases are enthusiastic, but medical experts say the idea is “at best premature and at worst reckless.”

multimedia.caption: Dr. Ren Xiaoping, left, an orthopedic surgeon in Harbin, China, plans to carry out full-body transplants, raising concerns among medical experts and ethicists around the world.
multimedia.copyright: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times

results.title: ACT, Citing Breach, Cancels Exam in South Korea and Hong Kong
results.abstract: More than 5,000 students were prevented from taking the college entrance test on Saturday in what a spokesman said was the first known nationwide cancellation in its history.

results.title: Australia Reconsiders How Far Flight 370 May Have Flown
results.abstract: As survey ships near the end of a search for the missing jet, officials take a last-ditch look at how far a plane might travel after using up its fuel.

results.abstract: The suspect, Virendra Tawde, is said to have clashed with Dr. Dabholkar over the physician’s crusade against spiritual practices he considered fraudulent.

results.title: The Chinese Hackers in the Back Office
results.abstract: A dusty old computer in a mom-and-pop Wisconsin welding shop is giving a digital security firm a window into the operations of Chinese hackers.

multimedia.caption: Cate Machine & Welding has allowed Area 1, a digital security company, to monitor the activity on a dusty, old server taken over by Chinese hackers so that potential victims of an attack can be warned.
multimedia.copyright: Lauren Justice for The New York Times

results.title: Greed, Passion, Lust, Betrayal, and the Olympics in Between
results.abstract: In Brazil, the popular TV serials called telenovelas have so tight a grip on viewers that even the Olympics on home turf take a back seat in prime time.

multimedia.caption: The actresses Nathalia Dill, left, and Juliana Carneiro da Cunha on the set of the telenovela “Liberdade, Liberdade,” at Globo’s studios in a suburb of Rio de Janeiro.

results.title: A French Minister Who Attracts Applause and Anger Considers a Bigger Stage
results.abstract: Emmanuel Macron has started what many consider a campaign in all but name to explore whether to challenge François Hollande as the Socialist candidate for president.

results.title: Could Long-Lost Amber Room Be Stashed in a Nazi Bunker in Poland?
results.abstract: A museum in the country’s northeast says it has evidence of a hidden chamber inside a compound used by German forces, and that it may contain the treasure lost during World War II.

multimedia.caption: A former German bunker in Mamerki, Poland. Researchers have uncovered evidence of a hidden chamber inside, and think it may contain loot from World War II.
A former German bunker in Mamerki, Poland. Researchers have uncovered evidence of a hidden chamber inside, and think it may contain loot from World War II.

results.title: A Chinese Delicacy Straight From the Swiftlet’s Mouth
results.abstract: Bird’s nest soup, including bird saliva, is supposed to improve the immune system, skin and sex drive. The demand means trouble for the birds themselves.

multimedia.caption: A caretaker held a bird’s nest and egg at the Swiftlet Eco Park in Perak, Malaysia, last year. Prized in China for their alleged health benefits, nests made from swiftlets’ saliva are a delicacy.

results.title: An All-Purpose Maze Deep Beneath a London Suburb
results.abstract: The Chislehurst Caves have been an arsenal, a bomb shelter, a concert site, a film set, and once even a makeshift maternity ward. But they’ve never been caves.

results.title: Europe and the Unthinkable
results.abstract: The collapse of the European Union is implausible but not impossible. It is time to awaken to the dangers.

results.title: Common-Sense Steps to Deal With the Migrant Crisis
results.abstract: People have been crossing the Mediterranean for years, trying to get to Italy. Why can’t the Continent come up with a good response?
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

results.title: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
results.abstract: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
results.byline: By DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
